clusters.title: ‘We’ve got to find answers’: Corby families affected by cancer searching for truth about toxic waste sites
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘We’ve got to find answers’: Corby families affected by cancer searching for truth about toxic waste sites

items.title: ‘We’ve got to find answers’: Corby families affected by cancer searching for truth about toxic waste sites
items.standfirst: Alison Gaffney believes her son’s rare leukaemia was caused by dumped toxic waste from the town’s steelworksAlison Gaffney and Andy Hinde received the devastating news that their 17-month-old son, Fraser, had a rare type of leukaemia in 2018.Two years of gruelling treatment followed, including chemotherapy, radiotherapy and immunotherapy, before a stem cell transplant. Fraser, then aged three, made a “miraculous recovery” from the surgery, before doctors declared the cancer in remission. Continue reading...
items.content: Alison Gaffney believes her son’s rare leukaemia was caused by dumped toxic waste from the town’s steelworksAlison Gaffney and Andy Hinde received the devastating news that their 17-month-old son, Fraser, had a rare type of leukaemia in 2018.Two years of gruelling treatment followed, including chemotherapy, radiotherapy and immunotherapy, before a stem cell transplant. Fraser, then aged three, made a “miraculous recovery” from the surgery, before doctors declared the cancer in remission. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Families in Corby are seeking answers about cancer cases.
They believe toxic waste sites caused the illnesses.
Alison Gaffney's son had a rare form of leukemia.
The families are searching for the truth about the waste.
The investigation involves health and environmental concerns.

clusters.title: Five key findings from our investigation into the Free Birth Society
clusters.neutral_headline: Five key findings from our investigation into the Free Birth Society

items.title: Five key findings from our investigation into the Free Birth Society
items.standfirst: Year-long investigation into multimillion-dollar business exposed serious concerns, from dangerous medical claims to FBS-linked stillbirths• Full story: How the FBS is linked to baby deaths around the worldThe Free Birth Society (FBS) is a business run from North Carolina that promotes the idea of women giving birth without midwives or doctors present.It is led by Emilee Saldaya and Yolande Norris-Clark, ex-doulas turned social media influencers who have gained a global following through the FBS podcast, which has been downloaded millions of times. Continue reading...
items.content: Year-long investigation into multimillion-dollar business exposed serious concerns, from dangerous medical claims to FBS-linked stillbirths• Full story: How the FBS is linked to baby deaths around the worldThe Free Birth Society (FBS) is a business run from North Carolina that promotes the idea of women giving birth without midwives or doctors present.It is led by Emilee Saldaya and Yolande Norris-Clark, ex-doulas turned social media influencers who have gained a global following through the FBS podcast, which has been downloaded millions of times. Continue reading...

items.title: ‘Ignorant and life-threatening’: experts condemn Free Birth Society misinformation
items.standfirst: Professionals say claims about birth, including excessive bleeding, blue babies and placenta care, are dangerous• Full story: How the FBS is linked to baby deaths around the worldThe Free Birth Society (FBS) is a multimillion-dollar business that promotes the idea of women giving birth with no medical assistance.It is led by two ex-doulas turned social media influencers: Emilee Saldaya and Yolande Norris-Clark. Neither have midwifery or medical training, but they claim to have extensive experience from attending the births of other women. Continue reading...
items.content: Professionals say claims about birth, including excessive bleeding, blue babies and placenta care, are dangerous• Full story: How the FBS is linked to baby deaths around the worldThe Free Birth Society (FBS) is a multimillion-dollar business that promotes the idea of women giving birth with no medical assistance.It is led by two ex-doulas turned social media influencers: Emilee Saldaya and Yolande Norris-Clark. Neither have midwifery or medical training, but they claim to have extensive experience from attending the births of other women. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Free Birth Society promotes unassisted childbirth.
The Society is a multimillion-dollar business.
The investigation revealed serious medical concerns.
The Society is linked to baby deaths.
The Society is led by two ex-doulas.

items.title: Being labelled a Highly Sensitive Person was validating and empowering – until it wasn’t | Miranda Luby
items.standfirst: An online personality quiz made me feel understood, but it also created a mental cageSometimes, taking an internet quiz on a random Tuesday night can change your life – first for the better, then for the worse.Are you bothered by intense stimuli, like loud noises, strong smells or caffeine? Are you deeply moved by the arts or nature? Do you become overwhelmed when a lot is going on around you? Do you have difficulty with big changes? Continue reading...

clusters.title: Boris Johnson took four days off as NHS warned Covid could ‘overwhelm’ system
clusters.neutral_headline: Boris Johnson Took Time Off During Critical Pandemic Period

items.title: Boris Johnson took four days off as NHS warned Covid could ‘overwhelm’ system
items.standfirst: Files show then PM was walking dog, riding motorbike and hosting guests as pandemic planning stalled in ‘lost month’Boris Johnson took four days off from official government business during a key period in the UK’s Covid preparation when the NHS was bracing to be “overwhelmed” by the virus.Official disclosure for the period in February 2020 – described by the Covid inquiry as a “lost month” in the country’s crisis response – reveal Johnson enjoyed an extended break during the half-term holidays at Chevening, a governmental estate in Kent, where he spent time walking his dog and taking motorcycle rides. Continue reading...
items.content: Files show then PM was walking dog, riding motorbike and hosting guests as pandemic planning stalled in ‘lost month’Boris Johnson took four days off from official government business during a key period in the UK’s Covid preparation when the NHS was bracing to be “overwhelmed” by the virus.Official disclosure for the period in February 2020 – described by the Covid inquiry as a “lost month” in the country’s crisis response – reveal Johnson enjoyed an extended break during the half-term holidays at Chevening, a governmental estate in Kent, where he spent time walking his dog and taking motorcycle rides. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Boris Johnson took four days off during a crucial period in February 2020.
The period was described as a "lost month" in the UK's COVID response.
Johnson spent time at Chevening, a government estate in Kent.
He was walking his dog and riding a motorcycle during his break.
The NHS was bracing to be overwhelmed by the virus at the time.

clusters.title: Bad season of bird flu in UK hits supply of Christmas turkeys

items.title: Bad season of bird flu in UK hits supply of Christmas turkeys
items.standfirst: Availability of chickens and ducks also expected to be tight, with 5% of the seasonal flock culled so farUK poultry producers are battling a “bad season” of bird flu, with cases much worse than at this point last year, putting a squeeze on supplies of Christmas birds including turkeys, chickens and ducks.Two industry insiders said they expected supplies of all poultry to be tight ahead of the festive season, especially for organic and free-range birds, which are seen as the most vulnerable to infection. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

ai_summary: UK poultry producers face a "bad season" of bird flu.

Availability of chickens and ducks is also expected to be limited.

clusters.title: My schoolmates mocked me for being a UPF-free, ‘weird lunchbox’ kid. Turns out my mum was right all along
clusters.neutral_headline: My schoolmates mocked me for being a UPF-free, ‘weird lunchbox’ kid. Turns out my mum was right all along

items.title: My schoolmates mocked me for being a UPF-free, ‘weird lunchbox’ kid. Turns out my mum was right all along
items.standfirst: In the 90s my mum embarrassed me with her rejection of ultra-processed foods – but the growing body of evidence about them is vindicating herA very specific childhood experience arose from being a “weird-lunchbox kid” growing up in the 90s with a food-conscious mother. It was the sense of palpitating trepidation felt when opening your school lunchbox, knowing that what lay within was going to be seen as “weird” in comparison with the sliced-white-bread-plastic-ham sandwiches, cheesy Wotsits and Club biscuits everyone else was gobbling.What’s that?” your classmate would ask, their nose wrinkling as they took in yesterday’s veggie curry, crumbling homemade falafel or – my mother’s speciality – a “deconstructed sandwich” of doorstop-thick fresh bread, filling of some kind (often cucumber) and attendant crumbs floating freely in the bag. (Why bother assembling at all?, my father asked once, when you could simply throw in all the elements and shake?)Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett is a Guardian columnist Continue reading...
items.content: In the 90s my mum embarrassed me with her rejection of ultra-processed foods – but the growing body of evidence about them is vindicating herA very specific childhood experience arose from being a “weird-lunchbox kid” growing up in the 90s with a food-conscious mother. It was the sense of palpitating trepidation felt when opening your school lunchbox, knowing that what lay within was going to be seen as “weird” in comparison with the sliced-white-bread-plastic-ham sandwiches, cheesy Wotsits and Club biscuits everyone else was gobbling.What’s that?” your classmate would ask, their nose wrinkling as they took in yesterday’s veggie curry, crumbling homemade falafel or – my mother’s speciality – a “deconstructed sandwich” of doorstop-thick fresh bread, filling of some kind (often cucumber) and attendant crumbs floating freely in the bag. (Why bother assembling at all?, my father asked once, when you could simply throw in all the elements and shake?)Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett is a Guardian columnist Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author recalls being mocked for a "weird lunchbox" in the 90s.
The lunchbox contained foods considered unusual by classmates.
The author's mother rejected ultra-processed foods.
The author's mother's choices are now being vindicated by evidence.
The author's classmates ate processed foods like white bread sandwiches.

clusters.title: Dangerous shortage of medics threatens safe patient care in England, top GP says
clusters.neutral_headline: Dangerous shortage of medics threatens safe patient care in England, top GP says

items.title: Dangerous shortage of medics threatens safe patient care in England, top GP says
items.standfirst: Exclusive: Royal College of GPs chair says surgeries desperate to hire more doctors but lack funding to do soGPs can no longer guarantee safe care for millions of patients because of a dangerous shortage of medics, Britain’s top family doctor has said.Prof Kamila Hawthorne, the chair of the Royal College of GPs (RCGP), said surgeries were desperate to hire more doctors to meet soaring demand for care but could not afford to do so because of a lack of core funding. Continue reading...
items.content: Exclusive: Royal College of GPs chair says surgeries desperate to hire more doctors but lack funding to do soGPs can no longer guarantee safe care for millions of patients because of a dangerous shortage of medics, Britain’s top family doctor has said.Prof Kamila Hawthorne, the chair of the Royal College of GPs (RCGP), said surgeries were desperate to hire more doctors to meet soaring demand for care but could not afford to do so because of a lack of core funding. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A dangerous shortage of medics threatens safe patient care in England.
Surgeries are desperate to hire more doctors.
Surgeries lack funding to hire more doctors.
The Royal College of GPs chair made the statement.
GPs can no longer guarantee safe care for millions of patients.

clusters.title: Two UK clinical trials to assess impact of puberty blockers in young people
clusters.neutral_headline: Two UK clinical trials to assess impact of puberty blockers in young people

items.title: Two UK clinical trials to assess impact of puberty blockers in young people
items.standfirst: Multi-year studies announced after Cass review found ‘insufficient evidence’ about effects on children with gender dysphoriaTwo studies to investigate the impact of puberty blockers in young people with gender incongruence have been announced by researchers in the UK after an expert view said gender medicine was “built on shaky foundations”.Puberty blockers were originally used to treat early onset puberty in children but have also been used off-label in children with gender dysphoria or incongruence. Continue reading...
items.content: Multi-year studies announced after Cass review found ‘insufficient evidence’ about effects on children with gender dysphoriaTwo studies to investigate the impact of puberty blockers in young people with gender incongruence have been announced by researchers in the UK after an expert view said gender medicine was “built on shaky foundations”.Puberty blockers were originally used to treat early onset puberty in children but have also been used off-label in children with gender dysphoria or incongruence. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Two UK studies will assess the impact of puberty blockers.
The studies follow a review finding insufficient evidence.
The studies will investigate young people with gender incongruence.
Puberty blockers were originally for early puberty.
The studies are announced after an expert view.

clusters.title: Influencers made millions pushing ‘wild’ births – now the Free Birth Society is linked to baby deaths around the world
clusters.neutral_headline: Influencers made millions pushing ‘wild’ births – now the Free Birth Society is linked to baby deaths around the world

items.title: Influencers made millions pushing ‘wild’ births – now the Free Birth Society is linked to baby deaths around the world
items.standfirst: A year-long investigation reveals how mothers lost children after being radicalised by uplifting podcast tales of births without midwives or doctorsAs Esau Lopez was asphyxiated for the first 17 minutes of his life on Earth, the atmosphere in the room remained serene, even ecstatic. Acoustic music crooned from a speaker in a modest two-bedroom apartment in a suburb of Pennsylvania. “You are a queen,” murmured one of three friends in the room.Only Esau’s mother, Gabrielle Lopez, felt something was wrong. She was pushing hard, but her son would not be born. “Can you help [him] out?” she asked, as Esau crowned. “Baby is coming,” the friend replied. Four minutes later, Lopez asked again, “Can you grab [him]?” Another friend murmured, “Baby is safe.” Six minutes passed. Again, Lopez asked, “Can you grab [him]?” Continue reading...
items.content: A year-long investigation reveals how mothers lost children after being radicalised by uplifting podcast tales of births without midwives or doctorsAs Esau Lopez was asphyxiated for the first 17 minutes of his life on Earth, the atmosphere in the room remained serene, even ecstatic. Acoustic music crooned from a speaker in a modest two-bedroom apartment in a suburb of Pennsylvania. “You are a queen,” murmured one of three friends in the room.Only Esau’s mother, Gabrielle Lopez, felt something was wrong. She was pushing hard, but her son would not be born. “Can you help [him] out?” she asked, as Esau crowned. “Baby is coming,” the friend replied. Four minutes later, Lopez asked again, “Can you grab [him]?” Another friend murmured, “Baby is safe.” Six minutes passed. Again, Lopez asked, “Can you grab [him]?” Continue reading...

ai_summary: An investigation links the Free Birth Society to baby deaths.
Influencers promoted "wild" births without medical professionals.
A baby died after 17 minutes of asphyxiation during a home birth.
The mother asked for help multiple times during the birth.
The atmosphere in the room was described as serene.

clusters.title: Control of HIV, TB and malaria at risk after global health fund donations fall
clusters.neutral_headline: Control of HIV, TB and malaria at risk after global health fund donations fall

items.title: Control of HIV, TB and malaria at risk after global health fund donations fall
items.standfirst: World leaders pledge just over $11bn, short of the $18bn experts say is needed to stay on track to tackle challengesControl of the deadly infectious diseases HIV, tuberculosis and malaria “hangs in the balance” after a shortfall in donations to a leading global health fund, advocates have warned.Only $11.3bn of the Global Fund to Fight Aids, TB and Malaria’s $18bn (£14bn) targeted budget for 2026 to 2028 has been confirmed so far. Continue reading...
items.content: World leaders pledge just over $11bn, short of the $18bn experts say is needed to stay on track to tackle challengesControl of the deadly infectious diseases HIV, tuberculosis and malaria “hangs in the balance” after a shortfall in donations to a leading global health fund, advocates have warned.Only $11.3bn of the Global Fund to Fight Aids, TB and Malaria’s $18bn (£14bn) targeted budget for 2026 to 2028 has been confirmed so far. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Donations to a global health fund have fallen short.
The fund aims to fight AIDS, TB, and malaria.
Experts say $18 billion is needed for the fund.
Only $11.3 billion has been confirmed so far.
Control of diseases is at risk due to the shortfall.

clusters.title: Coroners’ prevention of future deaths reports should be legally enforced | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Coroners’ prevention of future deaths reports should be legally enforced | Letters

items.title: Coroners’ prevention of future deaths reports should be legally enforced | Letters
items.standfirst: Christine and Francis Saunders, who lost their beloved daughter Juliet, respond to the news that advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales has been routinely ignoredThank you for your article on how coroners’ prevention of future deaths (PFD) reports are being routinely ignored (Coroners’ advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales routinely ignored, study finds, 19 November).Experience has shown us that a coroner’s PFD report is issued in response to serious systemic failings and a trust’s inaction to prevent future tragedies. Tolerating poor care and refusing to learn seem to be shared features of health scandals, including the treatment of people with learning disabilities, such as our own beloved daughter, Juliet Saunders, who died aged 25. Continue reading...
items.content: Christine and Francis Saunders, who lost their beloved daughter Juliet, respond to the news that advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales has been routinely ignoredThank you for your article on how coroners’ prevention of future deaths (PFD) reports are being routinely ignored (Coroners’ advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales routinely ignored, study finds, 19 November).Experience has shown us that a coroner’s PFD report is issued in response to serious systemic failings and a trust’s inaction to prevent future tragedies. Tolerating poor care and refusing to learn seem to be shared features of health scandals, including the treatment of people with learning disabilities, such as our own beloved daughter, Juliet Saunders, who died aged 25. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses ignoring coroners' reports.
The reports address systemic failings.
The authors lost their daughter, Juliet.
The daughter died at age 25.
The authors experienced poor care.

clusters.neutral_headline: Why thousands of NHS GPs are cutting their hours despite plan to increase access to doctors

items.title: Why thousands of NHS GPs are cutting their hours despite plan to increase access to doctors
items.standfirst: Just one in 13 early career GPs work full-time, NHS figures show, with job stress and childcare significant factorsMuch of the health secretary’s plans to reinvent the NHS hinge on moving services from bed-blocked, overstretched hospitals to “neighbourhood health centres” where possible, and to general practice.However, while Wes Streeting hopes to make it easier for patients to see their doctor, thousands of GPs have been dramatically cutting back their surgery hours in recent years. Continue reading...

Continue reading...
